overview_of_class: The emerging digital interaction technologies (e.g. sound recognition, computer vision, GPS, physical computing, and gestural interaction devices such as Wii and smartphone) are creating new expressive opportunities for digital media artists and game designers. In this course, we will investigate the affordances of existing and emerging digital environments. We will explore the use of these affordances for designing interactive stories.  We investigate the ways of designing interactive stories or interactive art pieces that make use of the procedural power of digital media thus giving the participant (player, user) maximum agency.
name: Topics in Interactive Media
title: SoC RTVF 376-0-20 Topics in Interactive Media
enrl_requirement: Enrollment Requirements: Pre-requisite: Students must have taken, be currently enrolled, or concurrently registered for RTVF 190 for the upcoming quarter.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The emerging digital interaction technologies (e.g. sound recognition, computer vision, GPS, physical computing, and gestural interaction devices such as Wii and smartphone) are creating new expressive opportunities for digital media artists and game designers. In this course, we will investigate the affordances of existing and emerging digital environments. We will explore the use of these affordances for designing interactive stories. We investigate the ways of designing interactive stories or interactive art pieces that make use of the procedural power of digital media thus giving the participant (player, user) maximum agency.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
We will read and discuss interaction design and expand our understanding of interaction design through analysis of digital and non-digital artifacts (films, novels, performance pieces, installations, and games). Participants will present one of the assigned texts and a artifact.

Participants will design, implement, and present one short interactive narrative or art piece in any interactive medium they choose. I will teach the basics of Adobe Flash and ActionScript 3 and QR codes which will enable participants to create their project. ActionScript will introduce you to the idea of using code as an expressive medium.

Participants may choose to collaborate for their Capstone Project.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will be evaluated based on their attendance and class participation, as well as 2-3 projects, and a final project.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Janet H. Murray, Inventing the Medium: Principles of Interaction Design as a Cultural Practice (The MIT Press, 2011).
Available as electronic copy through Northwestern University Library (free).
Book stores $50 + tax

overview_of_class: This course is a workshop for understanding the cultural context of video games through practical use of introductory game creation tools. The course aims to distinguish between how video games extend traditions of artistic exchange and how they offer novel and unexplored modes of communication unique to the medium. The course is designed to engender an active and critical perspective on what games are and how they relate to other cultural texts through analysis, discussion, production, and play. Students will have the opportunity to conceptualize their own game projects and select from a menu of approaches in order to resolve them. Students will be evaluated through active participation, individual exercises, reading responses, presentations, and unit projects in group critique. The course is designed for students with no prior game making experience, although students with experience are welcome to enroll.
